Violation_Type: Failure to meet residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c)
Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying the physical presence test instead of a qualitative analysis of residency
Application_Facts: El-Khader was physically present in Canada for 925 days out of the required 1,095 days within four years preceding application
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Court_Ruling: Federal Court upheld the Citizenship Judge's decision as reasonable
Defendant_Behavior: Insufficient physical presence in Canada during required period
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in applying quantitative physical presence test over qualitative residency analysis
Assessment_Factor: Duration and pattern of physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judge to Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Record of El-Khader’s physical presence (925 days)
Evidence_Assessed: Days of physical presence in Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturn of Citizenship Judge's decision and approval of citizenship application
Governing_Rule: Three years of residence in Canada within four years preceding application required under s. 5(1)(c)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient days of physical presence to meet statutory threshold
Outcome: Denial of citizenship due to failure to meet residency requirement
Decisional_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Cause_Description: El-Khader's citizenship application was denied due to insufficient physical presence in Canada as per s. 5(1)(c)
Evidence_Handling: Physical presence data was used to assess compliance with statutory requirement
Evidence_Assessment: Objective count of days present in Canada
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge’s application of the physical presence test was reasonable and consistent with statutory interpretation
